title: Non-Small-Cell Lung Cancer Treatment by Stage

content: After your lung cancer is diagnosed, the doctor will run tests to find out the size of the tumor and whether the cancer has spread to other parts of the body. This process is called staging. Knowing the stage of your disease is crucial because it will help you and your doctor choose the best course of treatment. Here’s a look at the options for each stage. Your doctor will make changes along the way to find what works best.

content_blocks.text: After your lung cancer is diagnosed, the doctor will run tests to find out the size of the tumor and whether the cancer has spread to other parts of the body. This process is called staging. Knowing the stage of your disease is crucial because it will help you and your doctor choose the best course of treatment. Here’s a look at the options for each stage. Your doctor will make changes along the way to find what works best.

sections.heading: STAGE 0
content: How It’s Defined The cancer is only in the lining of your airways. Treatments Surgery: If your health is good overall, surgery is probably all you need. Depending on where the tumor is, your surgeon will suggest one of these procedures: Wedge resection: Cut out the tumor and a small amount of normal lung tissue. Segmental resection (segmentectomy): Take out the part of the lung where the tumor is. Sleeve resection: Remove a lobe of the lung and a part of the airway. Lobectomy: Cut out an entire lobe of the lung. (The right lung is divided into three lobes; the left lung has two lobes.) Most surgeons prefer this option since it offers the best chance for a cure. Pneumonectomy: Take out the entire lung. This might sound extreme, but you can live a normal life with only one lung.

content_blocks.text: How It’s Defined The cancer is only in the lining of your airways. Treatments Surgery: If your health is good overall, surgery is probably all you need. Depending on where the tumor is, your surgeon will suggest one of these procedures: Wedge resection: Cut out the tumor and a small amount of normal lung tissue. Segmental resection (segmentectomy): Take out the part of the lung where the tumor is. Sleeve resection: Remove a lobe of the lung and a part of the airway. Lobectomy: Cut out an entire lobe of the lung. (The right lung is divided into three lobes; the left lung has two lobes.) Most surgeons prefer this option since it offers the best chance for a cure. Pneumonectomy: Take out the entire lung. This might sound extreme, but you can live a normal life with only one lung.

sections.heading: Photodynamic therapy (PDT):
content: This process uses a drug called a photosensitizer and a certain type of light to create a form of oxygen that kills nearby cells. It can help shrink tumors without the side effects of other drugs. Brachytherapy :  This is a form of internal radiation where radioactive material is put into a tumor or into an airway next to a tumor.

content_blocks.text: This process uses a drug called a photosensitizer and a certain type of light to create a form of oxygen that kills nearby cells. It can help shrink tumors without the side effects of other drugs. Brachytherapy :  This is a form of internal radiation where radioactive material is put into a tumor or into an airway next to a tumor.

sections.heading: STAGE I
content: How It’s Defined In stage IA, the tumor is no larger than 3 centimeters (about 1 1/4 inches) across and hasn’t spread to any other tissues or lymph nodes. In stage IB, it’s no more than 4 centimeters and has spread to the main bronchus of the lung’s lining, or both.

content_blocks.text: How It’s Defined In stage IA, the tumor is no larger than 3 centimeters (about 1 1/4 inches) across and hasn’t spread to any other tissues or lymph nodes. In stage IB, it’s no more than 4 centimeters and has spread to the main bronchus of the lung’s lining, or both.

Your doctor will make changes along the way to find what works best.

sections.heading: STAGE I
content: How It’s Defined In stage IA, the tumor is no larger than 3 centimeters (about 1 1/4 inches) across and hasn’t spread to any other tissues or lymph nodes. In stage IB, it’s no more than 4 centimeters and has spread to the main bronchus of the lung’s lining, or both.

content_blocks.text: How It’s Defined In stage IA, the tumor is no larger than 3 centimeters (about 1 1/4 inches) across and hasn’t spread to any other tissues or lymph nodes. In stage IB, it’s no more than 4 centimeters and has spread to the main bronchus of the lung’s lining, or both.

sections.heading: Treatments
content: Surgery: If you’re in good health, surgery may be all you need. Based on the tumor’s size and placement and how well your lungs work, your surgeon may suggest one of these procedures. Sleeve resection Segmentectomy or wedge resection (for tumors smaller than 2 centimeters across) Lobectomy

content_blocks.text: Surgery: If you’re in good health, surgery may be all you need. Based on the tumor’s size and placement and how well your lungs work, your surgeon may suggest one of these procedures. Sleeve resection Segmentectomy or wedge resection (for tumors smaller than 2 centimeters across) Lobectomy

sections.heading: Targeted therapy:
content: These drugs target specific parts in or on cancer cells. This therapy is sometimes given after surgery if there is a high risk of the cancer returning. Immunotherapy: These drugs help your immune system attack cancer. This therapy can be given after surgery if there is a high risk of the cancer returning. Chemotherapy: With any of these surgeries, nearby lymph nodes are also removed to see if the cancer has spread. If your medical team feels your cancer could come back, they’ll probably suggest you get chemo after surgery to destroy any leftover cancer cells. You might hear this called adjuvant chemotherapy. You could take a chemo drug by mouth or get it in a vein. Radiation: If you’re not healthy enough for surgery, your doctor may go with this therapy. It uses powerful X-rays to kill cancer cells. You may hear the doctor call it external radiation. Radiofrequency ablation (RFA): This is a procedure where heat produced by radio waves kills cancer cells.

content_blocks.text: These drugs target specific parts in or on cancer cells. This therapy is sometimes given after surgery if there is a high risk of the cancer returning. Immunotherapy: These drugs help your immune system attack cancer. This therapy can be given after surgery if there is a high risk of the cancer returning. Chemotherapy: With any of these surgeries, nearby lymph nodes are also removed to see if the cancer has spread. If your medical team feels your cancer could come back, they’ll probably suggest you get chemo after surgery to destroy any leftover cancer cells. You might hear this called adjuvant chemotherapy. You could take a chemo drug by mouth or get it in a vein. Radiation: If you’re not healthy enough for surgery, your doctor may go with this therapy. It uses powerful X-rays to kill cancer cells. You may hear the doctor call it external radiation. Radiofrequency ablation (RFA): This is a procedure where heat produced by radio waves kills cancer cells.

sections.heading: STAGE II
content: How It’s Defined The tumor is between 3 and 7 centimeters across, or it has spread to your lymph nodes, or both. Treatments Chemotherapy: Your doctor may want to do chemo (sometimes paired with radiation) before surgery to shrink the tumor. They might call this neoadjuvant chemotherapy. Even if your doctor doesn’t find cancer cells during surgery, they might suggest chemo afterward just in case cancer cells were left behind. Immunotherapy : Neoadjuvant immunotherapy is sometimes given before surgery to help shrink the tumor. It can also be given as additional treatment after surgery. Targeted therapy: These drugs are sometimes given as additional treatment after surgery. Testing for biomarkers can help determine if certain targeted therapies can help treat the cancer. Surgery: If you’re healthy enough, the doctor will likely recommend one of the following: Lobectomy Sleeve resection Pneumonectomy After surgery, your doctor will check the tissue they removed to see if cancer cells are at the edges. If so, you may need another operation to remove more cancer cells. Radiation: If you’re not healthy enough for surgery, you may get radiation instead.

sections.heading: STAGE III
content: How It’s Defined Cancer is found in the lung and in the lymph nodes in the middle of the chest. Stage III has three subtypes:

content_blocks.text: How It’s Defined Cancer is found in the lung and in the lymph nodes in the middle of the chest. Stage III has three subtypes:

sections.heading: STAGE IIIA
content: How It’s Defined If the cancer has spread only to lymph nodes on the same side of the chest where it began, it’s called stage IIIA. Treatments Chemotherapy and radiation: If you can stand the side effects, treatment usually starts with chemo. It might be combined with radiation. Surgery: If you’re healthy enough and your doctor thinks there’s a good chance they can remove any cancer that remains, they may suggest surgery. In some cases, it may be their first choice of treatment. A combination of chemotherapy and radiation therapy, or possibly immunotherapy may be given before surgery. Adjuvant therapy after surgery may be given with chemotherapy, targeted therapy, or immunotherapy. The type of surgery depends on the size and location of the tumor, how far the cancer has spread into the lymph nodes, and whether you’ve had surgery before.

content_blocks.text: How It’s Defined If the cancer has spread only to lymph nodes on the same side of the chest where it began, it’s called stage IIIA. Treatments Chemotherapy and radiation: If you can stand the side effects, treatment usually starts with chemo. It might be combined with radiation. Surgery: If you’re healthy enough and your doctor thinks there’s a good chance they can remove any cancer that remains, they may suggest surgery. In some cases, it may be their first choice of treatment. A combination of chemotherapy and radiation therapy, or possibly immunotherapy may be given before surgery. Adjuvant therapy after surgery may be given with chemotherapy, targeted therapy, or immunotherapy. The type of surgery depends on the size and location of the tumor, how far the cancer has spread into the lymph nodes, and whether you’ve had surgery before.

sections.heading: Immunotherapy:
content: There are many immunotherapeutic drugs options, depending on the type of lung cancer you have, any mutations or biomarkers that may be present, treatments you've already had, and your overall health. Your doctor can guide you through these choices. Targeted therapy: These drugs are sometimes given as additional treatment. Testing for biomarkers can help determine if certain targeted therapies can help treat the cancer.

Your doctor can guide you through these choices. These drugs are sometimes given as additional treatment. Testing for biomarkers can help determine if certain targeted therapies can help treat the cancer.

sections.heading: STAGES IIIB and IIIC
content: How It’s Defined The cancer has spread to lymph nodes near the opposite lung or in your neck. These cancers can’t be completely removed by surgery. Treatments Chemotherapy with radiation: Again, treatment depends on your overall health and how you can handle the treatments. If you’re in fairly good health, chemo and radiation might improve your condition. Radiation or chemotherapy: If you can’t handle the combo treatment, you’ll probably get radiation therapy alone. Chemo by itself is less common. Clinical trials: These cancers can be difficult to treat, so you may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial of newer treatments.

content_blocks.text: How It’s Defined The cancer has spread to lymph nodes near the opposite lung or in your neck. These cancers can’t be completely removed by surgery. sections.heading: STAGE IV
content: How It’s Defined The cancer has spread to both lungs, to fluid in the area surrounding the lungs, or to other organs. Treatments: Chemotherapy and radiation: A cancer that’s spread to distant sites in your body can be hard to cure. As long as you’re in fairly good health and can handle the side effects, treatments like chemotherapy and radiation can ease your symptoms and help you live longer. Immunotherapy: This involves drugs that help your body’s own immune system find and destroy cancer cells. Targeted therapy: These drugs target certain parts of cancer cells. A test can tell if you'll respond to this treatment.

content_blocks.text: How It’s Defined The cancer has spread to both lungs, to fluid in the area surrounding the lungs, or to other organs. A test can tell if you'll respond to this treatment.

sections.heading: Photodynamic therapy:
content: Doctors use light to kill cancer cells and shrink tumors. Stent: Lung tumors that have grown into an airway can cause trouble breathing or other problems. Your doctor puts a hard silicone or metal tube called a Stent into the airway to hold it open.

sources: American Cancer Society: “How is non-small cell lung cancer staged?” “Surgery for non-small cell lung cancer,” “Treatment Choices for Non-small Cell Lung Cancer, by Stage,” “Radiation therapy for non-small cell lung cancer,” “Targeted Therapies for non-small cell lung cancer,” “Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer Stages, "Immunotherapy for Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer."
meta_description: Chemotherapy and other treatments for non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC) can slow the progression of cancer and sometimes even cure the disease.
